title.narrative: Building on Early Successes to Speed the Transition to Responsible Gold

description.narrative: Solidaridad continued its participation in the IRBC Agreement (gold covenant). We chaired the IRBC working group on Increasing Collective Leverage (ICL) that organized an outreach event for the Dutch jewelry sector. We requested the Insurances Covenant to include the gold sector in their agreement (currently being negotiated), and we contributed to the review of standard setting for both the London Metals Exchange (LME) and the Fairtrade Gold standard. Solidaridad joined the Value Chain Analysis working group on Gold for the Dutch Banking Agreement. Together with the other members of the working group we completed research on how Dutch banks are linked to the gold mining sector. We successfully lobbied for inclusion of ASM and gender in the recommendations of this report. In 2019, Solidardad was elected to be the chair of the European Partnership for Responsible Minerals (EPRM). As a member we contributed to a proposal to assess expansion of EPRM’s mineral scope to other minerals, cobalt being under consideration now. Solidaridad became a member of the Secretariat and core group of the Working Group Women's Rights and Mining (WGWRM). The Gender in Mining Encyclopedia that was launched by WGWRM together with GIZ during the OECD Minerals Forum.

comment.narrative:
Gold covenant, EPRM, OECD Forum for Responsible Minerals, RJC and new in 2017: Working Group on Women's Rights an Mining.
The signing of Dutch Gold Sector International Responsible Business Conduct (IRBC) agreement was one of the major achievements of 2017 towards a more responsible gold sector. It is the first time that companies in the Dutch gold sector 1) start to work together in a multi-stakeholder partnership with government and CSOs, 2) commit to implement the voluntary OECD due diligence guidance in their supply chain and 3) agree to become more transparent on refiners used to process the gold in their supply chain. Roughly 70% of the companies and trade associations in the Dutch gold jewellery sector are covered by the IRBC agreement. Solidaridad played an important role in the negotiations to come to an agreement. We actively lobbied for the obligation for companies to publicize where they source their gold and what they do to manage the risk of human rights violations and environmental malpractices in their international supply chains. This lobby was successful, as public reporting on due diligence was included in the final agreement. In addition, due to the relationships established in the IRBC agreement, Fairphone and Philips approached Solidaridad to cooperate in a project addressing child labour issues in ASM mines in Uganda. The project is the first positive impact project among participants of the Gold IRBC agreement, and the participating companies have committed to using the gold from the project mines in their products.
With the upcoming revision of the two standards of the Responsible Jewellery Council (RJC) in 2018, Solidaridad has already started to advise in the process through the RJC standards committee. In addition to this, we are also participating in the development of a new sector standard that is based on the concept of progressive improvement. The criteria for existing standards such as Fairtrade Fairmined (FT/FM) are too high for most ASMs to satisfy; hence, there is no incentive for improvement in these mines. By focusing on achievable and continuous improvements, the new Market Entry Standard allows ASM mines to get access to international markets in an early stage while guaranteeing compliance with general OECD due diligence guidelines. It is hoped that this new standard will increase the uptake of gold from informal ASM mines by formal international gold buyers. During 2017, Solidaridad continued to build the European Partnership for Responsible Minerals (EPRM) as a board member. We were actively involved in the development of its monitoring and evaluation framework and in the design of the first call for proposals, which focused on improving the socioeconomic conditions for miners and mining communities.

comment.narrative: Solidaridad contributed to the Stakeholder Statement on ?Implementing Gender-Responsive Due Diligence and ensuring the human rights of women in Mineral Supply Chains?, this statement is endorsed by the OECD and signed by over 30 governments, companies and other stakeholders, leading to improved policies.

title.narrative: Sector organisations improve mechanisms, policies and regulations
# + kind of mechanisms, policies & regulations of sector organisations improved

comment.narrative: Via the Women's rights and mining workgroup, Solidaridad made recommendations to EITI, the global standard to promote the open and accountable management of extractive resources. Based on those recommendations the EITI Standard explicitly now includes the rights of women in mining. This is a significant improvement in the policies and means a big step in the way from gender transparency to accountability for the 53 implementing countries.
